Discharge requirements may vary depending on capability and limitations of the wastewater treatment system to handle ammonia.  Generally, discharge permits require the pH to be within a neutral range before discharge.  Ammonia water has a high pH.  .  In some cases the municipality may allow discharge of ammonia water if it is metered and diluted.  However, neutralizing the ammonia water either before or during discharge ensures compliance with the permit. You must also remember that, most permits do not allow discharge of slug loads.

Retention and Treatment

If the factory has no on-site treatment capability, the ammonia water will likely have to be retained and neutralized before discharge to the city sewers.  If the factory has an on-site pH control system or biological treatment system, the ammonia water can be neutralized while it is discharged, but it must be metered to prevent overload of the treatment system.

Purpose

To properly contain, treat, and dispose of ammonia generated during maintenance and repair of refrigeration systems and to prevent unauthorized releases of ammonia or ammonia water to the environment.

Applicability

This procedure applies to all Heinz facilities that operate ammonia refrigeration systems.

Procedure

Other than a failure of an ammonia refrigeration system, the most likely occasion when ammonia may be released is during maintenance and repair of system components.  The primary concerns during ammonia system maintenance are to ensure safe working conditions and prevent atmospheric releases of ammonia.  During maintenance, liquid and gaseous ammonia must be removed from equipment and pipelines.  The following steps summarize the procedures that can be used by factories to prevent release of liquid or gaseous ammonia during routine maintenance and repairs.  Each factory should have available a more detailed procedures on transferring or removing liquid ammonia in their PSM manuals or in applicable IIAR Bulletins.  IIAR Bulletin No. 107 provides guidelines for Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Plant Tie-ins.


Evacuation

A.Procedure for routine evacuation when dual stage ammonia system is operational.

1.Use valves to isolate the component requiring maintenance.
2.Connect pump-down hose between the isolated section and the low-pressure side of the ammonia system.
3.Evacuate the isolated section by transferring the ammonia to the low-pressure side.
4.Verify pressure is zero in isolated section. If possible allow the system to stand for several hours or overnight to allow the residual liquid ammonia to vaporize.
5.After an appropriate period of time re-check for zero pressure before opening the isolated section for maintenance.

6.If required, notify operators at wastewater treatment plant that ammonia water will be discharged through the process sewers per conditions determined during contingency planning.
7.Meter neutral ammonia water to process drain to dilute and to prevent a slug load discharge to the sewers.
8.If it is not necessary to neutralize ammonia water, meter it directly into the process drain to prevent slug load to sewers.
9.Continue until all vessels are empty, including any ammonia water collected in the secondary containment basin.
10.Neutralize and meter any overflows of ammonia water captured in the secondary basin.

C.Procedure for continuous neutralization and/or disposal of ammonia water.  The disposal process depends upon the capability to neutralize ammonia water on-site.

1.Before commencing a continuous release of ammonia water, know the pathway it will follow and make sure there are no related safety issues.
2.Notify operators at wastewater treatment plant that ammonia water will be discharged through the process sewers per conditions imposed under Section C.
3.Set up a vessel in a location that will overflow to process sewers and fill with water.  Keep the water on so there is continuous flow.  Plan for about two gallons of water for every pound of ammonia.
4.Connect a hose to the isolated section of the ammonia system and immerse the open end of the hose in the water vessel.
5.Adjust flow of dilution water to ensure ammonia is absorbed.  Monitor the vessel to prevent any ammonia from gassing off.  
6.Monitor the on-site wastewater treatment system to verify that pH of all discharged water is within permit limits.
